metadata.case_name: Appellant (Election Petitioner) v. Respondent No. 1 (Returned Candidate)

facts.text: Appellant, respondent No. 1, and eight others were nominated candidates for election to Mysore Legislative Assembly from Tarikere Constituency at general election held in January 1952.
Five nominated candidates withdrew; contest between remaining five including appellant and respondent No. 1.
Polling took place on 4th January 1952; votes counted on 26th January 1952.
Respondent No. 1 secured 8,093 votes (highest); appellant 8,059 votes; others 6,239, 1,644, 1,142 votes.
Returning Officer declared respondent No. 1 successful; published in Mysore Gazette on 11th February 1952.
Respondent No. 1 lodged return of election expenses; notice published on 31st March 1952.

Appellant filed election petition on 10th April 1952 challenging validity on grounds of election rules violation and corrupt practices by respondent No. 1 affecting result; prayed for declaration that respondent No. 1's election void and appellant duly elected.
Petition sent by registered post to Election Commission; received on 14th April 1952.
Election Commission referred matter to Election Tribunal, Shimoga; hearing on 25th October 1952.
Appellant applied for amendment under Order VI rule 17 CPC to modify prayer clause adding alternative prayer to declare entire election void.
Tribunal allowed amendment despite objection by respondent No. 1.

Tribunal framed 27 issues including: infringement of polling commencement time at Booth No. I Ajjampur (issue 1); hiring/procuring motor bus of Ahmed Jan (issue 5); assistance of Government servants (issue 6); false return of expenses (issue 12); election procured by corrupt practices materially affecting result (issue 14); petitioner would have majority but for practices (issue on para 33).
Tribunal by 2:1 majority found issues 1,5,6,11,12,14 in favour of petitioner; declared respondent No. 1's election void and appellant duly elected.
Respondent No. 1 filed application under Art 226 before Mysore High Court on 5th February 1953 for certiorari to quash Tribunal's proceedings and order.
Mysore High Court (Medappa CJ and Balakrishnaiya J) allowed petition, issued certiorari quashing Tribunal order on 11th January 1954.
Appellant obtained certificate under Arts 132(1) and 133(1)(c) Constitution; appealed to Supreme Court.
Polling at Booth No. I Ajjampur commenced 25-30 minutes after 8 AM, causing some voters to leave.
Respondent No. 1 procured service bus of Ahmed Jan (agent) to convey about 60 voters in two trips; bus bore respondent's symbol; with knowledge and connivance.
Respondent No. 1 took assistance of Government servant Paramesshwarappa (Patel) who canvassed for him including at polling booth.
Respondent No. 1's return of expenses false: omitted petrol for 6 other cars (Rs.1250), hiring/loan charges for cars/vans, dinner/hotel expenses; exceeded Rs.5000 limit.

legal_issues.text: On what grounds could the High Court under Art 226 issue certiorari to quash Election Tribunal's adjudication?
Whether such grounds existed in the present case to justify High Court's issuance of certiorari?
Did Tribunal act without jurisdiction in entertaining petition (limitation) or allowing amendment?
Did Tribunal act in excess of jurisdiction by deciding unpleaded issues or declaring appellant duly elected without basis?
Were there errors apparent on the face of the record in Tribunal's findings on polling delay, Government servant assistance, and false expenses return?

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court misdirected on facts and law; Tribunal did not act without jurisdiction, in excess, or with error apparent on face.
Petition presented in time (14 Apr within 14 days of 31 Mar publication); amendment only modified prayer, no change in averments, and original prayer granted.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.81(2)(b), Rule 119 Representation of People Act; s.83(3)

petitioner_arguments.text: Findings on bus procurement within pleadings (para 8,9 petition: by self/agents/with knowledge/connivance); evidence supported.
Materials supported declaring appellant elected: 34 vote margin; bus carried 60 voters likely for resp1; wiping out majority.

respondent_arguments.text: Tribunal without jurisdiction: extended limitation; allowed impermissible amendment beyond s.83(3).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of People Act ss.81,83(3); no general CPC power

respondent_arguments.text: Excess jurisdiction: decided unpleaded matters (Ahmed Jan agency/connivance); declared appellant elected on speculation, no finding he would get more votes.
Errors apparent: polling delay finding speculative (unknown voters for appellant); Govt servant mere canvassing not 'assistance'; expenses on no evidence/speculation.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.123(8), s.100(2)(c) Representation of People Act

court_reasoning.text: Certiorari issues for lack/excess of jurisdiction, violation of natural justice, or error apparent on face; supervisory not appellate; does not reweigh evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principles from English law adopted under Art 226: control over area of jurisdiction and observance of law.

court_reasoning.text: Petition in time: 14 days from 31 Mar excludes publication date; amendment immaterial as original prayer granted, no averment change.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No extension of limitation needed; s.83(3) not exclusive for prayer amendment.

court_reasoning.text: Bus issue within pleadings (paras 8,9); finding of procurement with knowledge/connivance based on evidence, not excess.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finding of fact on evidence, not outside pleadings.

court_reasoning.text: Declaration of appellant elected supported: 60 voters via bus >34 margin; Tribunal found majority but for practices.
Polling delay: Tribunal used for s.100(2)(c) voidness, not sole basis for declaring appellant elected; no patent error.
Govt servant: Facts (canvassing with resp1) support inference of assistance under s.123(8); not mere canvassing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Inference from facts not error on face.

court_reasoning.text: Expenses: Evidence (documentary/oral) for extra petrol Rs.1250, hiring/loan payments, dinners; not no evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Detailed review in Tribunal order; appellate might differ but not certiorari grounds.

holdings.text: High Court erred; no grounds for certiorari: no lack/excess jurisdiction or error on face.
Art 226 powers wide but not appellate; certiorari for grave jurisdictional errors/manifest injustice only.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the High Court's judgment and order issuing writ of certiorari, and vacated the writ quashing the Election Tribunal's order.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; writ vacated; Tribunal's order restored implicitly.

key_quotes.text: The supervision of the superior Court exercised through writs of certiorari goes on two points... One is the area of inferior jurisdiction... the other is the observance of law in the course of its exercise.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It is plain that certiorari will not issue as the cloak of an appeal in disguise.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes supervisory not appellate nature (from Northumberland case)

key_quotes.text: However extensive the jurisdiction [Art 226] may be, it seems to us that it is not so wide... as to enable the High Court to convert itself into a Court of appeal.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Hence on the 14th issue we hold that the petitioner would have obtained a majority of votes had it not been for the aforesaid corrupt practices on the part of the first respondent.
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: Tribunal's key finding on material effect upheld
